Let me preface this by saying I had a lot of fun and I'd highly recommend this, but it has some massive issues that hold it back from being truly great.

For the first 20 or so hours, the game is a blast! You send a bunch of characters with their own unique abilities against waves of enemies, knocking them down with balls like Breakout/Alleyway, earning temporary and permanent upgrades. You get an expandable home base to construct buildings to unlock more stuff. The majority of upgrades all feel substantial and feel like they have a tangible impact on progression.

The issues start when you run out of things to unlock, and it happens very suddenly. For me around the 20-25 hour mark. The only thing you can do at that point is replay the old levels but they run faster and the enemies have significantly more HP. Without the promise of rewards, the gameplay just isn't that compelling to make you want to redo the whole thing with bullet sponge foes. It's mostly just standing around and occasionally adjusting your aim, hoping your stats and the temporary random upgrades you get will be enough to win with.

Basically, progression pacing just smashes itself into a brick wall rather than gradually taper off. Had it been balanced better it could have easily doubled the longevity of the game. Put some of the building blueprints behind the Fast mode or New Game+ modes, because these modes don't have any rewards and therefore I have no reason to play them!

Also had many glitches happen, including enemies that don't leave the board after dying, menu's getting stuck and not letting me leave them and also hard crashing to desktop. The base building part is also frustrating, it does a lot of things where certain buildings need to be in close proximity to others to boost their effect, making it like a jigsaw puzzle and you're constantly moving pieces around temporarily to be used where needed, with no sort of template or undo options to streamline this.

As said, still do highly recommend this. It scratched an itch, but was over far earlier than I'd have liked. If you've seen the gameplay footage and have an idea of what to expect, it's all that and a bag of chips! Just don't expect it to be something you can keep plugging away at on and off over a long period.

I'll go back and do a few more achievements and then that's me done.

Frankly, I almost skipped this game because the Ricochet-like gameplay loop seemed similar to P2W mobile games. Thank god I didn't. Do you remember the days you were playing dozens of random games on ArmorGames, Kongregate, and Newgrounds? [b]This is it. [/b] Ball x Pit has the exact feeling of stumbling upon a gem on these websites.

For me this was a break from plot-heavy, hardcore, and brain-boiling games. You don't have to put hundreds of hours into this one, you don't have to keep a separate Wikipedia in your head to be effective, and you don't min-max every aspect and every decision to reach the juicy content. The developers felt the same way creating this project, and you can TELL when you're playing.

Basically, the game has two sides: the runs and the "village".

[h2] THE RUNS [/h2]

You shoot balls at enemies and try not to die. Sounds lame, but this is exactly where the execution is ahead of the idea. It's not one of the games where you get through the basics with every upgrade being "+10% armor/damage/speed/HP". The devs take advantage of what they have created. You can work around the direction of the shots, the "baby balls"(yes, it's called that), the bounces, the walls and the back of the field, friendly pieces, debuffs/AoE/DoT, and, of course, [b]BALL SYNERGIES.[/b]

Certain combinations allow several balls to evolve into something new by creating, for example, a radiation beam from a poison ball and a light ball. Possibilities are fun to explore and play around, but the apex of the offered fun are the [b]FUSIONS.[/b] 

Basically, every ball (incl. the evolved ones) can be combined to create an even more powerful ball, and you have all freedom in the world to utilize that. Oh, this ball passes through all enemies and freezes them? Oh, the other one applies bleeding to everything it touches? Combine them and you'll have a soaring monster that just freezes and bleeds everything on the screen.

To be fair, some of the balls feel way weaker than others, but for me it's closer to being a part of the experimenting rather than a balancing issue.

[h2] PLAYABLE CHARACTERS [/h2]

They are [b]actually[/b] different from each other. Not simply varying starting items and stats. The devs gave unique mechanics(even some truly meta stuff) to each character, making the process of building around their abilities always unique and fun.

[h2] THE LEVELS [/h2]

...are also quite good. Each level contains unique bosses, interesting enemies, and certain mechanics that influence your playstyle. By the way, it's not the usual roguelike "clear stage 1 to access stage 2, repeat every run". It's just 8 separate levels that you unlock as you progress, so there's that.

[h2] THE VILLAGE [/h2]

Are you familiar with action roguelikes that have some kind of lobby where you simply spend gold to unlock X or upgrade Y in a skill tree? Here you have a small city builder included, ranging from placing trees and farms to calculating the best building combinations Backpack-Battles-style. 

The only issue I've had is that the progression sometimes makes the game too easy. The powerups you unlock expanding your village bring [b]massive[/b] advantages to you. Because of that, struggling to complete a level feels like "I need to grind a bit more" instead of "I have to learn a bit more".

[h2] THE GRIND [/h2]

The grind, despite taking place in this game, is almost automated with the help of what the devs provide you. Have you thought of a character that [spoiler] literally picks the best choices for you [/spoiler] ? Or someone who...  [spoiler] PLAYS THE GAME FOR YOU ENTIRELY? [/spoiler] What about playing [spoiler] two characters at the same time [/spoiler] ? What about sending a character to [spoiler] complete a level on their own [/spoiler] ? Point is, there is a bit of grind but you can manage it however you prefer to.

[h2] NON-FUNCTIONAL STUFF [/h2] 

Meaning graphics, art direction, animation, music, bugs, etc. 

[b] Done well. [/b] These things are more subjective than objective, but they surely don't feel cheap, lazy or unfitting. As for the bugs, the only thing I've encountered was unaligned text in pop-ups on unlocked buildings(IIRC), so nothing major.


[h2] CONCLUSION [/h2]

This is an almost perfect example of what a casual game should be in 2025. Chill, fun, polished, and providing space for creativity in the core loop. If you need to take a break from stuff that is heavy for your mind or heart, play Ball x Pit and witness a great execution of a simple idea.

The outer gameplay loop is a strange kind of base-building placement game where you place buildings and then "harvest" by shooting workers ala pinballs into your town where they bounce off of buildings to produce resources or complete construction of said buildings. [b]Why did you play Ball x Pit?[/b]
Because, like a lot of other folk, I can't help but get hooked by a bit of RNG. I've played (though I'd say not mastered) quite a few roguelikes, and this one looked a lot like Vampire Survivors. Plus I'd been wanting to play something like Breakout quite badly.

[b]And you were let down.[/b]
Well, not at first. BxP does a lot of things - pretty much everything in fact - right. The gameplay is chaotic fun, there's a wide range of characters to play, and a few of them bring something really fresh to the gameplay and really change things up. The music is hypnotic and the power-ups a lot of fun to experiment with. The base-building offers another fun layer. Hence I really enjoyed playing BxP for a solid amount of time.

[b]Why the negative review then?[/b]
Well, that's a tricky one.
Let me point out a couple of things that sound - and are! - positives initially.
[list]
[*]While you can play a wide variety of characters, and each one of them can bring devastating tactical nous with it, in particular depending on the boss, it didn't really seem to matter that much which one, or rather which pair, you chose for a run. Ultimately, choosing the right power-ups seemed far more important from midgame onwards.
[*]Runs are really short (15 mins ish), so there's none of that sweaty-hands, lose-or-win stacking of difficulty.
[*]Sure, there are some really powerful combinations of balls and passives, but it seemed as if it only mattered that you evolved things, not that you chose certain game-breaking combinations.
[*]Base-building is good fun, and there's a lot to unlock, but ultimately, you don't need to waste a lot of thought on it, as metaprogression handles itself pretty automatically.
[/list]
Which is all fine, particularly for a gamer like myself, who likes to enjoy this type of game without referring to an Excel sheet (not that there's anything wrong with Excel). However, I noticed that things were going pretty smoothly, so much so in fact that whenever I unlocked a new level, I'd be able to beat it first go. Now, maybe that's just because I play ball so well, but I highly doubt that.
Ultimately these issues beg the question: Is this really a roguelike?
Sadly, and hence the thumbs-down, I've come to the decision that, to me, come midgame, BxP can more accurately be classified as an idler. And I'm not really into that.
Update: From late midgame onwards BxP devolves into watching a let's play video. Sad.

[b]What about achievements?[/b]
I haven't completed all of them yet, but I would say that - in the vein of an idler - these are very fair and fun and should unlock pretty naturally during general play.

Ball X Pit is a roguelite game with an Arkanoid-esque theme. Unfortunately, it succumbs to the same too-much-content trap as many roguelites, leaving a game with both tedium and balance problems.

Ball X Pit's UI is sleek. The graphics are smooth and well-animated, even with many balls moving at very high speeds, and its sounds are crunchy and enjoyable. Its controls are responsive and intuitive. The moment-to-moment play is in many ways its best feature. The only problem is that the player's moment-to-moment actions have limited impact. There are two reasons for this. The first is that, unlike in Arkanoid, having a ball get by you has very little impact -- a slight delay, slightly decreasing your DPS.

The second is the Big Roguelite Mistake. Rather than winnow down content to The Good Stuff or get balance to the Right Challenge, Ball X Pit includes everything and the kitchen sink, including enemies that are far too spongey to defeat. Don't worry! By grinding through the metagame you can unlock all these various options, many of which are bad, as well as straight numeric power to make the game beatable.

But do you want to? There's probably a good game under here somewhere. But most of the characters are similar or terrible, with just three or four who are both distinct and powerful, and the numeric power gradually swaps the game from "numerically impossible" to "trivially easy." In the mean time, most runs are the same, with the same per-run upgrades being (mostly) desirable every time.

In the end, Ball X Pit is a slick package with very little inside. Another year or two of development, mostly spent removing things rather than adding them, might have yielded a pretty great game, but what's here is a mess that's easy to pass up.

BALL X PIT is nothing new, but it merges existing gameplay mechanics into something that is "in fashion" now and can provide a lot of fun. 

What it doesn't do is provide any form of a challenge. Most roguelikes have progression mixed with challenge, so you can't exactly win almost any of them on the first try, no matter how skilled you are. 

However, BALL X PIT disregards skill part entirely. As long as you do bare minimum of thinking, which is to form a resemblance of synergy between your character and equipment, the rest does not matter. If you don't have the damage, you can't finish a level, but if you do, you can almost idle through a run. 

The base building isn't all that clever either - while it seems somewhat novel at the start, it's just flatout bonuses that make you stronger, so you can do more difficult missions that now cease to be difficult. 

TL;DR A nice looking package devoid of any skill requirement, bordering on an idle game.

- Art and opening cinematic suggest a grimdark story of woe and struggle, a battle to venture deep into the Ball Pit and... that's really it. There is no actual story to follow. The grimdark setting is only there for style reasons, but does not support the gameplay. There is no real connection or deeper meaning within each layer. - The Content inside feels... lacking. The gameplay is great, addicting, makes ya wanna go for one more run, but ya go deep enough and kinda that feeling starts to be overwhelmed by feeling of: Why? Why play this? Each new unlock or special Ball combination does not really have that OOMF to it, which is the driving force to make ya wanna go play more. There is no story to unlock. - Each new floor feels... extremely the same. I do not wanna get too much into spoiler territory, but recurring theme is of a small pool of "something" may it be frozen water to slip on, or lava that burns, or quicksand that slowls you down. But that is the only environmental hazard you usually have to worry about besides the enemies. Making the Experience... Stale. Repeating. With no real "new thing to learn".

So hear me out, I am not saying the game is bad. I am saying it is just not very Steam Deck friendly, and there are a few reasons why. The whole system where you shoot the balls against the wall at enemies, wherever they may be, just does not feel great with a joystick. I cannot really put my finger on why, but it never feels natural, and it leads to situations where you end up frustrated because you are not always sure how to deal with something. I am trying to keep this spoiler free, even though most of this is clear from screenshots, but the overall feel with a controller is just off.

Another thing that really does not feel good is the lack of information you can get with a controller. There is no hovering over anything to see what certain stats do or how some of the systems work. The game kind of assumes you already know these things, and with a controller you are locked into what you can and cannot access. In bullet hell style games you are usually confined to an area, which is totally understandable, but in this game the wall limitations and the way the rooms open up just do not feel great on the Steam Deck. You can only move so far before you get attacked, and it never really explains why you cannot go further. Again, it just feels uncomfortable with the Deck controls.

The last gripe I have is the forced prolonging of character unlocks through the harvest and build system. I do not mind progression or having to earn characters and resources, but it annoyed me that I had to jump into another mini game inside the game to get those resources, while also keeping track of buildings that affect things. None of that is easy to manage with a controller. I understand the design choice, but it just is not laid out in a way that feels good on the Steam Deck. Trying to play that Tetris style layout with the buildings, only to realize I needed one more resource and had to go in for a two second run, just made me ask why I was doing all of this in the first place.

I do not think it is a terrible game. I just think it is not something I want to play on a console or the Steam Deck. With a mouse and keyboard it makes a lot more sense because you can actually access the information quickly without needing to memorize an entire encyclopedia every time you want to make progress.

This is a fantastic game. I would generally recommend it. It feels quite close to deserving the "overwhelming positive" status on Steam. 

There are so many great elements of this game, the Tetris style base building is so much fun. The level design is great. The music and vibe is great. The main ending [spoiler] was beautiful, mesmerising.[/spoiler].

Some things to possibly improve:

- The NG+ experience could easily be improved. Add a new expensive NG+ building that allows higher gamespeeds, 4x, 5x, 6x speed. (Currently 1x, 2x and 3x). Going through the NG+ at a fixed gamespeed feels very sluggish to go through again. There should to be a way to speed through it as the power creep slows down drastically.

- Putting a time delay on gold mines means you can't just do the "mine a gold mine, then enter a level, die as fast as possible, then repeat gold mines" as the fastest way to get gold. It should be a minimum of 5 minutes between gold mines UNLESS you can pay for an additional run, like in the late game, otherwise goldmine spamming, dying, then returning to gold mine completely breaks resource gathering as soon as you can get your first gold mine.

- The discoverability is okay, some aspects could improve, such as what exactly is classes as "AOE" when creating a build for the Makeshift Sisyphus. Perhaps a small indicator within the Encyclopedia that clearly tells you if something is AOE or not. 
For passive power, the thresholds aren't clear, and once you get to a certain level of "passive power" it appears to not improve anymore? I don't see the passive items getting more powerful, at least not clearly. So it would be nice if the encyclopedia could clearly show an equation like " damage = intelligence * level(1.0,1.5.2.0)" etc.

- For the whole earlygame, I generally believe it would be more satifying to feel a sense of visual power progression by lowering the early game ball attack speed, fire rate and ball speed, but increasing the damage for a net equal amount of earlygame status. All subsequent attack speed increases after this would feel more visually clear, and ball speed could have higher scaling, so that lategame it's still similar.
